cards.frontContent: What does it mean to be a full-stack web developer?
cards.backContent: A full-stack web developer is a professional who has expertise in both front-end and back-end development of web applications. This means they are capable of working on all aspects of a web application, from designing the user interface to managing databases and server-side logic.

cards.frontContent: What is the relationship between HTML and CSS?
cards.backContent: HTML (Hypertext Markup Language) is responsible for structuring the content of a webpage, using elements like headings, paragraphs, and links. CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) complements HTML by handling the visual presentation, allowing developers to set styles like colors, fonts, and layout.

cards.frontContent: What is Git workflow?
cards.backContent: A Git workflow outlines a set of practices and conventions for managing code changes within a project using Git version control. It includes strategies for branching, merging, and collaborating on code, ensuring organized and efficient development processes among team members.

cards.frontContent: What command do we use to create a directory?
cards.backContent: mkdir someFolderName

cards.frontContent: What command do we use to change directory?
cards.backContent: cd someDirectoryName

cards.frontContent: What command do we use to create a file?
cards.backContent: touch someFileName

cards.frontContent: What command do we use to list all files and directories in the current directory?
cards.backContent: ls

cards.frontContent: Why do developers use git and github?
cards.backContent: Git and GitHub allow developers to collaborate with others on a project without the danger of them overwriting each other's code.

cards.frontContent: What is HTML?
cards.backContent:
• HTML is a markup language that tells web browsers how to structure your page.

  • HTML comprises various elements that provide structure and content.

  • Some common HTML elements include section headings, images, paragraphs, unordered lists, and links.

  • HTML Introduction

cards.frontContent: What is CSS?
cards.backContent:
• CSS is the language we use to style a Web page.

  • CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets

  • CSS describes how HTML elements are to be displayed on screen, paper, or in other media

  • CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once

  • External stylesheets are stored in CSS files

  • CSS Introduction

cards.frontContent: What is a terminal (CLI)?
cards.backContent: A terminal, also known as a command-line interface (CLI), is a text-based interface for interacting with a computer's operating system. It allows users to enter commands in the form of text and receive text-based feedback or responses from the system.

cards.frontContent: What is a GUI?
cards.backContent: Graphical User Interfaces (GUIs) are the way most individuals interact with a computer. They rely on visual elements like windows, icons, and buttons.

cards.frontContent: What is git?
cards.backContent:
Git is a version control system used to track changes in computer files and coordinate work on those files among multiple people.

Key Concepts

  • Version Control: Git allows you to keep a history of changes to your codebase. This means you can revert to an earlier version of your code, compare changes over time, and collaborate with others more effectively.

  • Repository (Repo): A Git repository is a collection of files and the entire history of those files. There can be local repositories on your computer and remote repositories hosted on servers like GitHub, GitLab, or Bitbucket.

  • Commit: A commit is a snapshot of your repository at a specific point in time. It represents a set of changes made to your files. Each commit has a unique identifier.

  • Branch: A branch is like a parallel version of your repository. You can create branches to work on new features or fixes without affecting the main or "master" branch. Once you're satisfied with your changes, you can merge them back into the main branch.

  • Merge: Merging is the process of integrating changes from one branch into another. This is typically done when you've completed work on a feature branch and want to incorporate it into the main branch.

  • Pull Request (PR): In the context of platforms like GitHub, a pull request is a way to propose changes to a repository. It allows others to review the changes before they are merged.

  • Clone: Cloning a repository means creating a local copy of a remote repository. This is typically done when you want to work on a project that is hosted on a platform like GitHub.

  • Push: Pushing is the process of sending your local commits to a remote repository. This allows you to share your changes with others or back them up on a remote server.

  • Pull: Pulling is the process of fetching and merging changes from a remote repository to your local repository. This is how you get the latest updates made by others.

  • Conflict: A conflict occurs when Git is unable to automatically merge changes from different branches. This happens when two or more people have modified the same part of a file.

  • Repository Hosting Services: These are web-based platforms that provide Git repository hosting along with additional features like issue tracking, collaboration tools, and more. Examples include GitHub, GitLab, and Bitbucket.

Git is an essential tool for software development and is also used in various other fields where version control is needed, such as in writing, data analysis, and documentation management. It's a fundamental skill for many developers and is an integral part of modern software development workflows.

cards.frontContent: What are GitHub and GitLab?
cards.backContent:
• Purpose: GitHub and Gitlab are competing web-based platforms that provide a hosting service for version control using Git.

  • Features

    • Code Hosting: It allows users to host their Git repositories on GitHub's servers.

    • Collaborative Development: GitHub offers tools for collaboration, such as issue tracking, pull requests, code review, and project management.

    • Community and Social Features: Users can follow projects, contribute to open-source projects, and interact with other developers.

    • Integrations: It integrates with various third-party services, like continuous integration platforms and code quality tools.

cards.frontContent: What is markdown?
cards.backContent:
Markdown is a lightweight markup language that is used to format plain text documents.

Markdown allows you to add formatting elements such as headers, lists, links, and emphasis (like bold or italics) using simple and intuitive syntax. It's widely used in situations where a document needs to be easily readable in plain text, but may also be converted into a more structured format like HTML.

Markdown is often used for writing documentation, creating blog posts, and even in places like forums where you want to format your text without the need for a rich text editor. There are many tools and platforms that support Markdown, and it's a popular choice among writers and developers for its simplicity and flexibility.

Here are some basic examples of Markdown syntax:

Headers

# This is a Heading 1
## This is a Heading 2
### This is a Heading 3

Lists

- Item 1
- Item 2
  - Subitem A
  - Subitem B

Links

[Link Text](http://example.com)

Emphasis

*italic* or _italic_
**bold** or __bold__

Code

`inline code`

Blockquotes

> This is a blockquote.

cards.frontContent: What is a Readme.md?
cards.backContent:
README.md files are used by developers for project documentation.

These files are written in Markdown, a lightweight markup language that's easy to read and write.

Markdown Article

Markdown Cheat Sheet

cards.frontContent: What are HTML attributes?
cards.backContent:
HTML attributes provide additional information about an element and are always included in the opening tag. They are typically name-value pairs, separated by an equals sign (=), and the value is enclosed in double or single quotes.

Here's an example of an HTML element with attributes:

<a href="https://www.example.com" target="_blank">Click here</a>

  • href specifies the URL that the link points to.

  • target defines how the link should be opened. In this case, it's set to _blank, which means the link will open in a new tab or window.

cards.frontContent: What is an HTML id attribute?
cards.backContent:
The id attribute specifies a unique id for an HTML element. The value of the id attribute must be unique within the HTML document.

The id attribute is used to point to a specific style declaration in a style sheet. It is also used by JavaScript to access and manipulate the element with the specific id.

The syntax for id is: write a hash character (#), followed by an id name. Then, define the CSS properties within curly braces {}.

In the following example we have an <h1> element that points to the id name "myHeader". This <h1> element will be styled according to the #myHeader style definition in the head section:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<style>
#myHeader {
  background-color: lightblue;
  color: black;
  padding: 40px;
  text-align: center;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<h1 id="myHeader">My Header</h1>

</body>
</html>

w3Schools HTML Attribute

cards.frontContent: What is the HTML class attribute?
cards.backContent:
The HTML class attribute is used to specify a class for an HTML element.

Multiple HTML elements can share the same class.

The class attribute is often used to point to a class name in a style sheet. It can also be used by a JavaScript to access and manipulate elements with the specific class name.

In the following example we have three <div> elements with a class attribute with the value of "city". All of the three <div> elements will be styled equally according to the .city style definition in the head section:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<style>
.city {
  background-color: tomato;
  color: white;
  border: 2px solid black;
  margin: 20px;
  padding: 20px;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="city">
  <h2>London</h2>
  <p>London is the capital of England.</p>
</div>

<div class="city">
  <h2>Paris</h2>
  <p>Paris is the capital of France.</p>
</div>

<div class="city">
  <h2>Tokyo</h2>
  <p>Tokyo is the capital of Japan.</p>
</div>

</body>
</html>

w3schools class attribute

cards.frontContent: How do we connect a css style sheet with an html page?
cards.backContent:
To connect a CSS stylesheet with an HTML page, you can use the <link> element in the <head> section of your HTML document.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
    <head>
        <title>My Web Page</title>
        <link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="styles.css">
    </head>
    <body>
        <h1>Hello, World!</h1>
    </body>
</html>

cards.frontContent: What are CSS properties?
cards.backContent:
CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) properties are attributes that define the visual style and layout of HTML elements on a webpage.

They control aspects such as colors, fonts, spacing, positioning, and more. CSS properties work in conjunction with CSS selectors, which specify which HTML elements the properties should be applied to.

Here are some common CSS properties and a brief description of what they do:

  1. color: Sets the color of text content.

  2. font-family: Specifies the typeface or font of text.

  3. font-size: Sets the size of the font.

  4. font-weight: Defines the thickness of characters in a font.

  5. line-height: Specifies the height of a line of text.

  6. background-color: Sets the background color of an element.

  7. margin: Controls the space outside an element.

  8. padding: Defines the space inside an element.

  9. border: Sets the border around an element.

  10. width and height: Determine the dimensions of an element.

  11. display: Defines how an element should be displayed (e.g., block, inline, inline-block).

  12. position: Specifies how an element is positioned (e.g., relative, absolute, fixed).

  13. float: Allows an element to be floated to the left or right of its container.

  14. clear: Controls how elements should behave when clearing floats.

  15. text-align: Sets the horizontal alignment of text.

  16. vertical-align: Controls the vertical alignment of inline elements.

  17. list-style-type: Defines the type of bullet or numbering for lists.

  18. text-decoration: Controls text decorations like underline, overline, etc.

  19. overflow: Specifies how content should behave when it overflows its container.

  20. box-shadow: Adds a shadow effect to an element.

  21. border-radius: Rounds the corners of an element.

These are just some of the many CSS properties available. Each property can take various values (e.g., colors can be specified using color names, hexadecimal values, RGB values, etc.). Additionally, properties can be combined and customized to create complex layouts and styles.

Remember, CSS is a powerful styling language that allows for a high degree of control over the appearance of web content. Its properties and values can be quite extensive, and they can be used in conjunction with one another to achieve a wide range of visual effects.

cards.frontContent: What are CSS Selectors?
cards.backContent:
A CSS selector selects the HTML element(s) you want to style.

Here are some common types of CSS selectors:

  1. Universal Selector (*): Selects all elements on a webpage.

  2. Type Selector (or Element Selector): Selects all elements of a specific type (e.g., div, p, h1).

  3. Class Selector (.): Selects elements with a specific class attribute. For example, .example targets all elements with class="example".

  4. ID Selector (#): Selects a specific element with a given ID attribute. For example, #header targets the element with id="header".

  5. Descendant Selector (whitespace): Selects an element that is a descendant of another specified element. For example, div p selects all p elements that are descendants of div elements.

  6. Child Selector (>): Selects an element that is a direct child of another specified element. For example, div > p selects all p elements that are immediate children of div elements.

  7. Adjacent Sibling Selector (+): Selects an element that is immediately preceded by a specified element. For example, h2 + p selects the p element that directly follows an h2 element.

  8. General Sibling Selector (~): Selects all elements that are siblings of a specified element. For example, h2 ~ p selects all p elements that are siblings of h2 elements.

  9. Attribute Selector ([attr=value]): Selects elements with a specific attribute and value. For example, [type="text"] selects all elements with type="text".

  10. Pseudo-class Selector (:): Selects elements based on their state or position. For example, :hover selects an element when it's being hovered over.

  11. Pseudo-element Selector (::): Selects specific parts of an element, such as the first line or first letter. For example, ::first-line targets the first line of text in an element.

These selectors can be combined and nested to create more specific and targeted selections. For example, you might use a combination like div.container p.highlighted to target paragraphs with class "highlighted" that are descendants of div elements with class "container".

CSS selectors are a crucial part of applying styles to HTML elements and allow for fine-grained control over the appearance of a webpage.

cards.frontContent: What are developer tools in the browser?
cards.backContent:
All major browsers come with integrated developer tools. These tools allow us to inspect and debug the pages HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

To Open Dev Tools in Google Chrome, right click on the page and select inspect or ...

If using windows the command Ctrl + Shift + I will open dev tools

If using mac the command Option + ⌘ + J will open dev tools

cards.frontContent: What is the display property in CSS?
cards.backContent:
The display property in CSS determines how an HTML element should be displayed on a webpage. It can take various values, each affecting the layout and behavior of the element.

Here are some common values for the display property:

1. block:

- The element will generate a new block-level box. It will start on a new line and stretch the full width of its parent container.

- Example: <div>, <p>, <h1>, <ul>, <li>, etc.

2. inline:

- The element will generate an inline-level box. It will not start on a new line and will only take up as much width as necessary.

- Example: <span>, <a>, <strong>, <em>, <img>, etc.

3. inline-block:

- The element will generate an inline-level box, but you can set a width and height, and the element will respect these dimensions while still behaving as an inline element.

- Example: It's often used for elements like buttons or images that need to be inline but may have specific dimensions.

4. none:

- The element will not be displayed on the page. It will be completely removed from the document flow, as if it didn't exist.

- Example: This is often used in conjunction with JavaScript to toggle the visibility of an element.

5. flex:

- The element becomes a flexible container, and its children become flexible items that can be aligned in various ways within the container.

- Example: This is used for creating flexible layouts.

6. grid:

- The element becomes a grid container, allowing you to create complex grid-based layouts.

- Example: This is used for creating grid-based layouts.

7. table:

- The element will behave like a table element. It will generate a block-level box that behaves like a table.

- Example: This is used when you want to achieve table-like layout without using actual <table> elements.

8. inline-table:

- Similar to table, but it behaves like an inline element. It will not start on a new line.

- Example: This is used when you want a table-like layout without causing a line break.

9. list-item:

- The element will generate a block-level box that is also a list item. This is used for styling list items in ordered (e.g., <ol>) and unordered (e.g., <ul>) lists.

10. inherit:

- The element will inherit the display value from its parent element.

These are some of the most common values for the display property, but there are a few more specialized values and combinations. It's important to note that not all values are applicable to all elements. For example, a <div> element can be set to display: flex, but a <span> cannot. Always consult the documentation for specific details on what values are valid for each element.

cards.frontContent: What is the Box Model in CSS?
cards.backContent:
The CSS Box Model

In CSS, the term "box model" is used when talking about design and layout.

The CSS box model is essentially a box that wraps around every HTML element. It consists of: margins, borders, padding, and the actual content.

The image below illustrates the box model:

Explanation of the different parts:

  • Content - The content of the box, where text and images appear

  • Padding - Clears an area around the content. The padding is transparent

  • Border - A border that goes around the padding and content

  • Margin - Clears an area outside the border. The margin is transparent

w3Schools CSS Box Model

cards.frontContent: What is the difference between inline and block elements?
cards.backContent: Inline elements only occupy as much width as needed and do not automatically start a new line. Whereas Block elements always start on a new line and occupy as much width as there is available.

cards.frontContent: What is the margin property used for?
cards.backContent: Margin is used to create space around elements, outside of any defined borders.

cards.frontContent: What are the different values for the position property?
cards.backContent:
Static

  • default page flow

Relative

  • positioned relative to normal position

  • setting top, right, bottom, left properties will cause it to be adjusted from its normal position

  • other content will not be adjusted

Fixed

  • positioned relative to viewport

  • always stays in the same position, even when scrolling

  • top, right, bottom, left properties are used to position element

Absolute

  • positioned relative to the nearest positioned ancestor

  • top, right, bottom, left properties are used to position element

cards.frontContent: What is the position property?
cards.backContent:
The position property is used to control the positioning of elements on a web page. It determines how an element is positioned within the document's layout.

The default position is static, meaning that the element is positioned based on the normal flow.

When an element's position is relative, it stays in the normal flow but can be offset by a value provided in the CSS.

When an element's position is absolute, it is no longer in the normal flow but instead is positioned relative to its ancestor element and is determined by values provided for top, bottom, left, and right.

An element in the fixed position is also not in the normal flow. However, unlike absolute, the position is determined in relation to the viewport.

cards.frontContent: What is CSS?
cards.backContent:
• CSS is the language we use to style a Web page.

  • CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets

  • CSS describes how HTML elements are to be displayed on screen, paper, or in other media

  • CSS saves a lot of work. It can control the layout of multiple web pages all at once

  • External stylesheets are stored in CSS files

cards.frontContent: What is a CSS Selector?
cards.backContent: A CSS selector is a pattern used to select and apply styles to specific HTML elements on a webpage. It defines the target element(s) for styling within a CSS rule. Selectors can be based on element names, class names, IDs, attributes, and more, allowing developers to precisely control the appearance and layout of a webpage's content.

cards.frontContent: What are CSS Properties?
cards.backContent: CSS properties are attributes that define the visual presentation and behavior of HTML elements on a webpage. They determine aspects like colors, fonts, spacing, layout, and more. Each property has a specific value associated with it, which dictates how the chosen style will be applied to the selected elements. For instance, the color property sets the text color, and the font-size property determines the size of the font. CSS properties are fundamental in customizing the look and feel of web pages.

cards.frontContent: Why do we use media queries?
cards.backContent: We use media quires to deliver a tailored style sheet to desktops, laptops, tablets, and phones.

cards.frontContent: How would you center a box using the flexbox layout model?
cards.backContent:
Create a flex container and use justify-content and align-items

// CSS
.container {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
}

// HTML
<div class="container" >
  <div>
    Hello World
  </di>
</div>

cards.frontContent: What can we do with the CSS transform property?
cards.backContent: We can use the transform property to rotate, scale, and skew CSS boxes.

cards.frontContent: Why do we use CSS resets?
cards.backContent: CSS resets are used to erase browser default styling.

cards.frontContent: What is a use case for pseudo-classes?
cards.backContent:
Changing the styling of a button when a user hovers their cursor over said button.

.btn:hover {
  background-color: red;
}

cards.frontContent: What are data attributes used for?
cards.backContent: Data attributes are used to store custom data in an html element.

cards.frontContent: What is a wireframe and why do we use them?
cards.backContent:
• A wireframe is a tool used by developers to create basic UI/UXs. It allows us to visualize how our webpages will look, act and feel before we do any actual coding.

  • Wireframes can be hand-sketched or created with digital tools (google sheets, excalidraw, framebox, or figma).

cards.frontContent: Why do we use CSS Variables?
cards.backContent:
We use CSS Variables to:

  • make code easier to read

  • make it easier to change CSS values, such as color

cards.frontContent: How do we declare and use CSS Variables?
cards.backContent:
We declare variables globally in the root or universal selectors using a custom property name that begins with a double hyphen (--) and a property value that can be any valid css value.

:root {
   --main-text-color: brown; 
}

To use a css variable, we call the var() function with the custom property inside, in place of a regular property value.

p {
  color: var(--main-text-color);
}

cards.frontContent: What is a merge conflict?
cards.backContent: Merge conflicts happen when you merge branches that have competing commits and Git needs your help to decide which changes to incorporate in the final merge.

cards.frontContent: What are objects in JavaScript?
cards.backContent:
In JavaScript, objects are data structures that allow you to store and organize related data using key-value pairs. They can hold various data types, including strings, numbers, arrays, functions, and even other objects.

var car = {
  make: "Honda",
  model: "Civic",
  color: "Blue",
  numberOfWheels: 4,
  isSedan: true,
  honk: function () {
    console.log('HONKING');
  },
};

cards.frontContent: What is a function?
cards.backContent:
A function is a reusable piece of code.

function addTwoNumbers(firstNum, secondNum) {
  return firstNum + secondNum;
}

cards.frontContent: When working on a front-end application, where does our JavaScript Code run?
cards.backContent: In the browser.

cards.frontContent: How do we connect html and js files?
cards.backContent:
With a script tag.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Document</title>
</head>
<body>
  <main>
    <h1>Hello World</h1>
  </main>
  <script src="../some/file/path.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

cards.frontContent: What does a console.log() do?
cards.backContent: It prints a value to the console in the browser dev tools.

cards.frontContent: How do we declare a variable?
cards.backContent: var customVariableName = "some value"

cards.frontContent: What are the primitive types in js?
cards.backContent: strings, numbers, booleans, undefined, and null

cards.frontContent: In an 'if' statement, what must happen for the associated codeblock to run?
cards.backContent:
The conditional statement must result in a true value.

var age = 22;

if (age >= 21) {
  console.log("You may now enjoy some adult beverages.");
}

cards.frontContent: How would we console.log() the first value in an array?
cards.backContent:
var staffMembers = ["Abe", "Ben", "Cleo"];

console.log(staffMembers[0]);

cards.frontContent: How do we iterate over an array?
cards.backContent:
With a for-loop or an array method

var staffMembers = ["Abe", "Ben", "Cleo"];

for (var i = 0; i < staffMembers.length; i++) {
  console.log(staffMembers[i]);
};

staffMembers.forEach((member) => {
  console.log(member);
});

cards.frontContent: How do we call an Object Method?
cards.backContent:
var dogObj = {
  name: "Sebastian",
  bark: function() {
    console.log('Bark!!')
  }
};

dogObj.bark();

cards.frontContent: What does the key word 'this' refer to, in JavaScript?
cards.backContent: It refers to the a parent Object.

cards.frontContent: What is the DOM?
cards.backContent: The DOM, or Document Object Model, is a programming interface for web documents. It represents the structure of a document as a tree-like model where each node corresponds to an element (e.g., a paragraph, a heading, an image) or an attribute of the document.

cards.frontContent: What is event delegation?
cards.backContent: Event Delegation is a pattern based upon the concept of Event Bubbling. It is an event-handling pattern that allows you to handle events at a higher level in the DOM tree other than the level where the event was first received.

cards.frontContent: What is localStorage?
cards.backContent: The localStorage object allows you to save key/value pairs in the browser.

cards.frontContent: How do we set the value of an html attribute using JavaScript?
cards.backContent:
var aTag = document.querySelector("#some-div");

aTag.setAttribute("href", "https://google.com")

cards.frontContent: How do we create an html element and append it using JavaScript?
cards.backContent:
var displayedListUlEl = document.querySelector("#displayed-list");
var liEl = document.createElement("li");

liEl.textContent = "This is an li element created using JavaScript."

displayedListUlEl.appendChild(liEl);

cards.frontContent: How do we set an interval?
cards.backContent:
var sayHelloEverySecond = setInterval(function () {
  console.log("Hello!")
}, 1000);

cards.frontContent: How do we clear an interval?
cards.backContent: clearInterval(nameOfInterval);

cards.frontContent: How would we add an event listener to a button?
cards.backContent:
var buttonEl = document.querySelector("#button-one");

buttonEl.addEventListener("click", function () {
  console.log("Hello World")
});

cards.frontContent: What is event bubbling and how do we stop it?
cards.backContent:
• Event Bubbling is when an event travels up the DOM tree, creating a chain reaction of events.

  • We stop it by calling event.stopPropagation();

    var buttonEl = document.querySelector("#button-one");

buttonEl.addEventListener("click", function (event) {
  event.stopPropagation();
  console.log("Hello World");
});

cards.frontContent: How do you access a data attribute in JavaScript?
cards.backContent:
var divEl = document.querySelector("#div-el");

var someValue = divEl.dataset.endOfDataAttributeName;

cards.frontContent: How do we set an item into local storage?
cards.backContent: localStorage.setItem("userId", "1234");

cards.frontContent: How do we get an item from local storage?
cards.backContent: localStorage.getItem("userId");

cards.frontContent: How do we set an object or array into local storage?
cards.backContent:
var user = {
  userId: "1234",
  firstName: "Caleb",
  lastName: "Crum",
  email: "caleb@test.com"
}

localStorage.setItem("user", JSON.stringify(user));

cards.frontContent: How do we get an object or array from local storage?
cards.backContent: var user = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("user"));

cards.frontContent: What is jQuery?
cards.backContent:
• jQuery is a lightweight, "write less, do more", JavaScript library.

  • The purpose of jQuery is to make it much easier to use JavaScript on your website.

  • jQuery takes a lot of common tasks that require many lines of JavaScript code to accomplish, and wraps them into methods that you can call with a single line of code.

  • jQuery also simplifies a lot of the complicated things from JavaScript, like AJAX calls and DOM manipulation.

cards.frontContent: What is the difference between a library and a framework?
cards.backContent: Both the frameworks and libraries are both reusable pieces of code that help developers accomplish common tasks more efficiently. However, libraries target a specific functionality, while frameworks try to provide everything required to develop a complete application.

cards.frontContent: What is a CDN?
cards.backContent: A CDN, or Content Delivery Network, is a distributed network of servers strategically positioned in various data centers across the globe. Its purpose is to deliver web content (such as images, videos, scripts, stylesheets, and other resources) to users in a way that maximizes speed, reliability, and efficiency.

cards.frontContent: What is a CSS framework?
cards.backContent: A CSS framework is a pre-prepared library of CSS files and (often) JavaScript files that developers can use as a foundation for styling their web projects. It provides a set of standardized, pre-written code to help developers create responsive and visually appealing websites or web applications more efficiently.

cards.frontContent: What in order to use jQuery, what do we need within our html?
cards.backContent: A script tag linking to jQuery.

cards.frontContent: Why would we use jQuery?
cards.backContent: We use jQuery to makes it easier to use JavaScript on our website.

cards.frontContent: How do we create an html element and append it using jQuery?
cards.backContent:
var displayedListUlEl = $('#displayed-list');
var liEl = $('<li>');

liEl.text("This is an li element created using JavaScript.");

displayedListUlEl.append(liEl);

// Easy Way
var liEl = `<li>This is an li element created using JavaScript.</li>`

$('#displayed-list').append(liEl);

cards.frontContent: What is Bootstrap and why do we use it?
cards.backContent:
• Bootstrap is a CSS Framework used to quickly add styling to a webpage.

  • Bootstrap is essentially a very large stylesheet that offers a lot of solutions for layout and design needs, reducing the amount of custom CSS that developers need to create for their apps.

cards.frontContent: What does the Bootstrap Layout consist of?
cards.backContent: Containers, Rows, and Columns

cards.frontContent: How many columns are in each Bootstrap row?
How do we apply margin using bootstrap?
cards.backContent: <p class="m-2">Hello World</p>

cards.frontContent: What is an example of a jQuery UI Widget?
cards.backContent: A Dialog

cards.frontContent: What is an example of a jQuery UI Interaction?
cards.backContent: A Sortable List

cards.frontContent: Why do we use Day.js?
cards.backContent: We use dayjs().format() to format dates and times.

cards.frontContent: What does git revert do?
cards.backContent: git revert is used to undo a commit

cards.frontContent: What is JSON?
cards.backContent:
• JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation

  • JSON is a lightweight data-interchange format

  • JSON is plain text written in JavaScript object notation

  • JSON is used to send data between computers

  • JSON is language independent *

cards.frontContent: How does the client-server relationship work?
cards.backContent: The client is like a customer making requests, and the server is like a waiter fulfilling those requests. They communicate over a network using specific rules (protocols). The client sends a request, the server processes it, and sends back a response. This happens in a stateless manner, meaning each request is independent. For security, data is often encrypted, and authentication ensures only authorized clients access services. Scalability ensures efficient handling of many clients.

cards.frontContent: What is an API?
cards.backContent: An API, or Application Programming Interface, is a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate and interact with each other. It defines the methods and data formats that applications can use to request and exchange information, enabling seamless integration between different systems or services.

cards.frontContent: Where is curl used?
cards.backContent: In the command line.

cards.frontContent: What is the built in browser method that fetches resources over a network?
cards.backContent: fetch()

cards.frontContent:
What is wrong with the following code?

  fetch("https://api.github.com/orgs/nodejs/repos").then(function (data) {
    console.log(data);
    for (var i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
      console.log(data[i]);
    }
  });
cards.backContent:
The response needs to be converted to JSON.

  fetch("https://api.github.com/orgs/nodejs/repos")
    .them(function (res) {
      return res.json();
    })
    .then(function (data) {
      console.log(data);
      for (var i = 0; i < data.length; i++) {
        console.log(data[i]);
      }
    });

cards.frontContent: What does an HTTP response in the 200's mean?
cards.backContent: A status code in the 200's indicates a successful response.

cards.frontContent: What does an HTTP response in the 400's mean?
cards.backContent: A status code in the 400's indicates a client error response.

cards.frontContent: What does an HTTP response in the 500's mean?
cards.backContent: A status code in the 500's indicates an internal server error.

cards.frontContent: Why do we use URL parameters?
cards.backContent: URL parameters are used to make specific requests for resources.

cards.frontContent: Why do we use query parameters?
cards.backContent: Query parameters are used to pass and filter data within a request.

cards.frontContent: How can we change a users URL/location in the browser?
cards.backContent:
Using the window location object.

location.href, location.assign(), etc

cards.frontContent: Why do we set up GitHub branch protections?
cards.backContent: To ensure no one overwrites a branch by pushing to it directly. Instead, we require a pull request to merge branches.

cards.frontContent: What is cURL?
cards.backContent:
cURL, which stands for client URL, is a command line tool that developers use to transfer data to and from a server.

At the most fundamental, cURL lets you talk to a server by specifying the location (in the form of a URL) and the data you want to send.

What is Curl? (Article)

cards.frontContent: Besides fetch(), what are some ways to request data from a server-side API, while working on the client (browser)?
cards.backContent:
An XMLHttpRequest, or XHR for short, was the predecessor to fetch(). XHR requests involve much more code than a simple fetch().

AJAX is another alternative to the Fetch API. AJAX requests require the use of the third-party library jQuery to work.

Axios is also a third-party library that makes HTTP requests simple.

cards.frontContent: What do we use the Network Activity tab in Dev Tools for?
cards.backContent: We can use the Network Activity Tab in Dev Tools to view the loading of local and remote resources.

cards.frontContent: How do we know if an HTTP request has been made successfully?
cards.backContent:
HTTP responses have status codes that indicate whether a specific request has been successfully completed.

MDN Docs on Status Codes
